title: Does reading make you a smarter person? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are different kinds of intelligence and “smartness.” Reading does several good things: It allows you to rapidly review and pick out information you want to learn more about.It then allows you to learn more, even in a fairly great degree of depth, about things that might otherwise take you months to learn in an educational program.It helps you pick up skills in determining what is true and what is false in the information you are being bombarded with every day through media that are all too often controlled by those with enough money to make their visuals more attractive and memorable. “Flashy Pics” does NOT equal “good information.”It helps you develop your own language and writing skills. You do NOT develop a high-level vocabulary through studying dictionary definitions. You develop it through reading millions of words in which you have seen less common words used repeatedly in different contexts by accomplished writers — and thereby gotten a real “FEEL” for how those words are properly used and what they really mean.It allows you to take FULL CONTROL over what you want to specialize your knowledge and skills around, rather than have to sit through a lot of peripheral material that may really have nothing to do with where you want to focus your attention and build your strength.It allows you to efficiently see and gain information and arguments that both SUPPORT your point of view on an issue and also QUESTION your point of view on that issue…. so that ultimately you can be comfortable in knowing that you are “right” enough in your position that you can comfortably offer up your statements to the public while knowing you can competently defend against any attacks made upon them.READING IS ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT SKILLS YOU CAN HAVE! If you have children, one of the best things you can do for them is to teach them to enjoy reading. Let them see how you are able to tell them the stories they love because you are able to hold that magical thing called a book in your hands and turn the pages for the story while they sit in your lap. Show them how to recognize some simple words even if they don’t know the alphabet yet. And once they DO start to read, make getting books for them a special present… something you get for them on a regular basis (e.g. My father always brought home a new “Tom Swift” or “Hardy Boys” book on his biweekly paydays and I’d be waiting eagerly for it.) and something that becomes one of the most special treats with something big and unusual on holidays and birthdays. Heehee… Like most kids, I would wake up on Christmas morning as my parents were trying to catch up on the sleep they’d missed due to shopping and wrapping and decorating over previous days. I’d then try to wake them up so we could start unwrapping Santa’s gifts. They had a solution for that: They’d tell me that Santa probably left me one SPECIAL gift way out in front of all the others and that I could open that and play with it until they came down. That gift, of course, would be some big special book (E.G. a National Geographic Book Of Insects) that would occupy me happily for HOURS!) Ultimately all that early love of reading transformed into college and graduate school scholarships and my own love for writing my own articles and books about things that were important to me. So yes… reading WILL make you smart in ways that you would not have been otherwise! It’s one of the best things you can do with your time before you hit your late teens and get all preoccupied with late-teen stuff! MJM, who actually has about 5,000 books in his home library — heh, admittedly many of them being sci-fi and vampire novels rather than special relativity tomes, but hey… they’re still good books!

Is reading books really makes you smart? Before getting into a proper response to answering your question, I like to share some broad perspectives about reading. A lot of folks think that they are smart after reading a lot of books. And they probably think you have a lot of "knowledge". I like to say unequivocally that they have only a lot of "information", and not "knowledge". To me, as I have responded to earlier questions on Quora, "information" is just an organised gathering or collection of facts that are conceptually coherent and personally relevant to oneself. A post or a book or a magazine article or even a news broadcast that one has just read and/or heard and understood, is "information". "Information" becomes useful as soon as you can see through it, from the standpoint of a specific pattern of relationship, or "connecting the dots" as Steve Jobs so eloquently put it for us, to come up with an "idea" i.e. the creative process, of using it to create a productive outcome or a concrete deliverable in your life, in your work, in your business, or even for your client(s). That's to say, there has to be a personal relevancy to action, in order to determine the usefulness or viability of "information". Upon putting the "idea" to work, then only one gets to know whether the "idea" has worked, or didn't work. Better still, one may even get to know what might help to make it work better, faster, or even smarter, the next time round. This is then aptly called, "experience". Over time, cumulative "experience" then becomes "knowledge". Putting this initiative in another way, reading a series of posts or books or magazine articles or even listening to a news broadcast, is "information", or what I like to call "word experience". Through execution and implementation with all the sweat equity, and not forgetting adapting and evolving in different application contexts through time, only then, one gets "knowledge", or what I like to call "world experience". The Smartest Person of the 20th Century Albert Einstein is believed to have said: "Knowledge is experience; everything else is just information!” Think about it. The Internet is invariably packed with lots of "information" (Sad to say, with all the Good, the Bad and the Ugly). A lot of folks always think that by just googling, they have lots of "knowledge". To sum up my point, "knowledge" is not measured by what's stored in the head; it's what you do and what you don't. That's to say, your ultimate productivity matters the most! OK, now, back to your question: As long as you have made full use of your evolving knowledge from reading to create productive outcomes or construct concrete deliverables that eventually could add/compound/multiply value to your life, say as a student, or to your work, or to your business, or even to your client(s), as a professional, you have become a lot smarter than those who don't. [2016_Reading and Knowledge]

The people who are saying “no” or “not really” have never read anything outside of fiction. Yes, books will make you smart, very smart. They are, quite simply, a key to intelligence. They offer far more (valuable) information than what any video on Youtube, Khan Academy, or anywhere else has to offer. Take someone who learns a subject over the internet versus someone who learns from books, and the books person always wins by a long shot. Books have been and still are the elite form of education, mainly because of the quality of the content contained within them. However, it depends on what you read and how you apply it. Being intelligent isn’t just knowing stuff. As Einstein once said, “Any fool can know. The point is to understand.” The “understand” part is very important. There is no point to knowing stuff if you can’t or don’ t know how to use what you know. It would be like an artist learning everything there is to know about drawing but never actually draws anything in their life. Simply reading books is not enough. Intelligence is represented in terms of information. There is information in books, but there is also a load of information that is obtained from physical experience, information that would be way too dense to just fit into a book and expect readers to remember. It’s for this reason that intelligence is not limited in its definition. You can be intelligent in dancing, making music, drawing, writing stories, mathematics, physics, chemistry, etc. Whatever you decide to learn, make sure you do your due diligence in selecting your book first. Don’t rush it and also, try to avoid the “most popular book”. The most popular books are often the most generic books, which means you’ll get generic perspectives. Instead, find influential figures in your field and see if they wrote any books. Often times they are more difficult reads, but very rewarding. The logic here is simple: If you have an option to learn from a master, don’t just settle with someone that is good or great.

Reading teaches you to absorb information quickly - the better you can read, the less effort your brain uses to process language, leaving more brain power to deal with the meaning rather than the language syntax and grammar. A lot of people love to read fiction - I think this is more about entertainment than any intellectual growth. At some point all fiction deals with the same old human interactions - in fact there are just a few archetypal plots that cover 90% of stories.  Science fiction does introduce some things to think about - but many science fiction writers just take a regular old fantasy story and rename stuff based on scientific terms. Disc world, Hunger Games and so on fall in this genre. On the whole - fiction is like eating only candy - it makes you feel good, but it’s not challenging your ability to think abstractly - also experiencing emotion tends to lower your power to think - so a book that makes you feel typically dumbs you down. Reading non-fiction is useful - one kind of nonfiction is informational books - one has to be careful when choosing books that talk about facts. Some fields of knowledge have no facts, rather only speculation - Self help books lie in this category - they present some hypothesis, but give no real evidence or a line of reasoning that can follow. “Law of attraction”, “Sun signs” and so on fall in this genre - they just fill your head with some notions that have no basis and cannot ever stand up to scientific scrutiny. Another non-fiction genre is the textbook - this is full of fact, but tends to focus on memorization rather than abstraction. Reading these kinds of books too much (as you do in college) your brain ends up like this:  The next genre is popular science - Many authors like Stephen Hawking, Richard Dawkins, Michio Kaku, Harari, Taleb have become popular. The ones who write about physics sometimes tend to oversimplify things. But they remain mostly accurate.The books that deal with subjects that are not very rigorous tend to push a certain agendas or theories without emphasizing the speculatory and hypothetical nature of the book. Another genre is the philosophical book - this includes books dealing with human nature as well as books dealing with abstract philosophy.Once again, many authors often try to push ideas rather than present them as hypotheticals. Books on socialism are often like this. Ultimately books are like food - they contain memes just like food contains bacteria - some memes help you survive, but some memes survive at your expense. One has to have a balanced diet - build a strong immune system against memes, and examine them critically before infusing them into your brain. Facts are very useful memes - facts never mutate, and can be regenerated from scratch. Ideologies, stories, fantasy and philosophy are useful for survival, but there ate plenty of harmful or wasteful ones too. The conclusion is that reading fills your brain with stuff, but it is not guaranteed that it always makes you smarter. If you want to grow muscle, you need to eat a lot - but that doesn’t mean eating will make you more muscular.It depends on how you process that food. Same for books - it’s not only about quantity, or even quality of the material you read, but also how your brain deals with the ideas and memes in it.

Do books make you smarter? I’m really not sure they do, in and of themselves. When I was in 8th grade, in the late ‘70’s, we had a quiet “reading period,” sponsored by the parent-teacher association (PTA), every afternoon. At that time it didn’t matter what we read, all that mattered was that we were reading. At home, much to my mother’s chagrin, I was a bookworm. But I never brought my personal books to school, so, during the daily reading hour, I was forced to choose something to read from the cardboard box at the front of the room. I can still see that box, covered loosely with hideously bright floral wrapping paper, so appropriate to what it held. I’m guessing the PTA donated their cast-off paperbacks and magazines in order to make their program successful, because half of what that florid box contained were Harlequin Presents Romances. (The other half of the box was filled with old sports and fashion magazines so, naturally, I chose the books with the swooning lovers on the cover). If you’re not familiar with Harlequin Romances they are, or at least they were at that time, formulaic romance stories focusing on a heroine who is frequently drawn to a mysterious man with whom she falls hopelessly and shallowly in love at some weekend spent at a fairy tale country manor or estate. Another way of describing them would be “PG-13 bodice rippers.” I’d never encountered books like these before. Or since. I clearly remember being critical of the terrible writing, plots, and the flagrant stupidity of the cast of unbelievable characters. Did those books make me smarter? I doubt it. Garbage in, garbage out. Of course the experience did give me some insight into the reading habits of the average PTA mom, so on that level, maybe the books made me smarter. Or, sadly, a little biased. In any case, I chose not to join the PTA when I had the opportunity, some 20 years later.

On average,they do. But that solely depends on your choice of literature. Good books are the ones that help you with your personal growth,teach you something whether it’s a life long lesson or better vocabulary. Good books are a miniature universe on their own.Once you start reading them,you become a part of the plot. Isn’t it amazing that you are reading a person’s thoughts and life experiences who lives,perhaps,thousands of miles away and which you’re never going to meet in person? But virtually,not only have you met them but have also become a part of their incredible circle of learners. Such books are not necessarily massive scientific journals. They could be entire bundles of fiction and essay analysis but if you are in the correct mindset,you become a better human after reading them. Bad literature is what I like to say,an increase in carbon footprint and a waste of space. I have read terrible literature. In the writer’s community,it is considered a good thing to read the ‘not-so-good narratives’ and use them as templates as to how to not write a book. Erotic literature has sales higher than ever.Massively stupid trilogies are ever so popular but people still spend their time and energy flippping through the leaflets whether it is a learning experience or not. In the olden times,the purpose of reading books was not to become smarter but they were read for the sake of learning because there were no other knowledge gateways. In the modern times,those who read books are deemed smarter because it is viewed as the classic form of learning. Consider it yourself. Who appears more scholarly :- One who reads from a kindle or one who is devoted to a leather bound volume? People now willingly force themselves to set goals for reading actual books for the sake of becoming smarter. So from a standard viewpoint,we can safely conclude that books (good or bad) do make you smarter but only if you read them with the correct mindset and intentions.

Infinitely smarter. OK, I know some people are going to point out that it has little effect on your IQ score, once you've grown up, anyway. Fluid intelligence, which is what an IQ test tries to measures, doesn't increase with age -- in fact, once we're past 14, it starts to decline. But most of what we consider smartness isn't what we figure out for yourselves. It's what other people have figured out for us. That knowledge, and the skills we learn and practice, are called crystallized intelligence. Even an Einstein doesn't figure most things out -- if he did, he'd be a very advanced caveman! Well, not even that, because the caveman benefited from the geniuses who invented flint knives, clothing, and controlled fire, not to mention some heavy-duty hunting and gathering techniques without which one would rapidly starve. Crystallized intelligence, unlike fluid intelligence, increases as we get older. And while we can get some superficial information from TV or YouTube or just talking to people, real understanding still requires that we read, not just online, but books. I don't think you have to become a bookworm to be knowledgeable -- or even that that's desirable -- but you do need to read the central books in your field, and also the most important general books -- the classics and books that come along, a few a year, that have a major influence on our culture. Back when I was working, I'd read technical papers, data books, manuals, patents, and textbooks. And then when a problem came up or someone needed to know how to do something, I'd have the answer and everyone would say "How did you know that?" and call me a genius. And meanwhile, I was thinking "But it's only because I read the manual," LOL, Once you have knowledge, both general and specific, you'll find yourself understanding much more, able to do much more, and being tapped as a resource by people who will then consider you really, really smart.

I don’t really care to elaborate that much because the answer should be pretty obvious that it’s BOTH. However, I read a LOT. But I read in spurts. That is, sometimes I’ll read 8 hours per day for weeks at a time. I usually read all kinds of topics too, from medical science, to philosophy, economics, physics, occasionally some fiction and self-help stuff as well. Other times, I will get trapped into a video game or other hobbies that are less intellectually stimulating. My personal anecdote reveals that when I am in a state of constant reading, I tend to be more productive at work and quite sharp, being able to relate a lot of things to what I have been reading about. I make more progress on personal projects and I seem to reflect better internally when I think about things. To understand why reading can actually make you smarter, it requires some level of understanding about neuroscience. Your brain is nothing but a big recording device that responds to the environment. Genes merely modulate how exactly your brain responds to each stimuli. Reading books, encountering all these bits of data and insight can physically (literally) reshape and restructure your brain, which is ultimately what determines someone’s “intelligence”. Of course, people who are smart are also more likely to read. It’s a positive feedback loop! Side note: Reading ITSELF has some affect on brain structure (like exercise has on muscles), but the content of the material is probably more important. It must actually provide useful knowledge, items of insight, etc. Sort of like training your muscles to do a specific task rather than to just be “strong”. You must also actively apply your new knowledge and insight, otherwise it just fades away, again like unused muscle lol. Thanks for reading my view and opinion on this subject. :) Studies and references can easily be supplied upon request.

Smarter? Maybe not but it defenitly gives you a new perspective. You've probably heard the saying “inspiration can strike from anywhere", what this means is the more you read and the more you widen your reading selection, you get fresh percepctives. Let's try to see it as an example, Say you read Issac Assimovs Robot series  This is a science fiction book where the author imagines a future with robots almost reaching a sentient state(singularity), how the rules of robotics might be and how it would effect humanity. You might start thinking about how a robot would think if it were very intelligent and start to dwell on similar subjects like AI. Next you read a book about finance  This book talks about various aspects of stock market the basics and some tips for getting started in stock market investment. At first glance these don't seem to convey more than they intend to but take a step back and look at it together and you get a plethora of ideas. For example you could think of the potential application of AI in finance and how it might help analyse portfolios, inverse it and you might be able to come up with an actual estimation of the money required to come up with the best robots and see where it can be optimized. True genius lies in application and forming connection where it isn't obvious, that is how people like Elon musk make a difference apart from there passion it's the perception. Hope this motivates you to read and read voraciously. Peace

Yes, but you can learn faster when you be like Da Vinci and focus on these techniques. Let me elaborate. There are three classes of people: those who see, those who see when shown, and those that do not see. - Leonardo Da Vinci No doubt. I am a big fan of the great thinkers. My top thinker of all time? It has to be Da Vinci. Why you ask? For his abilities in learning and creativity, without a doubt. A mathematician. A scientist. An engineer. An anatomist. A creative and learner. Always learning and creating. Do you see? Maybe the lessons from Da Vinci will help. So what would be the lessons in learning and creativity derived from Da Vinci? Here are the ones I continually come back to: Sketching and note taking Over his lifetime Da Vinci created 13,000 pages of sketches and notes. 13,000 pages. By hand, on individual sheets of paper. A sketch in the center, simple and done quickly, label on top, annotations along the sides, arrows pointing to key content. Sometimes a short summary on the bottom. Divergent thinking first Alone for the first few iterations divergent thinking. Time to generate lots of ideas, and to reflect. Incubate ideas. Ask himself lots of questions. Always observing and studying. Think about the age of Da Vinci … no computers, few books, and few experts in fields of his interests. Just his ability to see and observe using notes to record for further study. Convergent thinking later Da Vinci often reviewed his work with respected peers after he had finished incubating his ideas. It was an opportunity to refine his ideas. Time to collaborate. He was way ahead of his time in most topics, so many of his good ideas were rejected. He didn’t lose his desire or his persistence by the rejections. But remember … 13,000 sketches led to at least 3 masterpieces. Persistence is a key, isn’t it? Perhaps this is the most important reason we have less creative people. Save and revisit later Most of Da Vinci’s sketches were done on individual sheets of paper. Not in a constrained notebook. He understood the value of multiple revisits and connecting, reconnecting, and grouping related facts and observations. An analogy expert. And an uncanny ability to connect several different observations and ideas to create new ideas. You should know these: Top Notch Educated Person ... 12 Traits You Will Recognize Defer judgment His basis of study was simple observation and notes/questions on his observations. He withheld judgments, either positive or negative, for as long as possible. Particularly his own. He appreciated that judgment would be a block to creativity and new ideas. “The greatest deception men suffer is from their own opinions” Curiosity and questions Perhaps Da Vinci’s greatest asset was his insatiable curiosity. The more observations and connection of ideas, the more questions and curiosity. And creative ideas. Stimulate imagination Da Vinci used divergent thinking to create lots of ideas. Lots of ideas, questions, and curiosity to stimulate his imagination. He minimized the limitations and constraints when using his imagination to think of the solution space to his many questions. Do you see? Very, very few of Da Vinci’s abilities are in the populace. But that doesn’t mean you can’t learn to be creative … it can be learned. Can you use these lessons to learn to see or see better? Give it a try. Practice and be persistent. Stick with it and over the long haul you will see some good dividends. NO! Lemme explain. The first thing is many people here are attributing different things to reading, like having more vocabulary, knowing more about the world, etc. But you don't get that from reading, you get that from learning. And you can learn many different ways, not just by reading. So people shouldn't boast that they read many books. someone can watch a lot of tv and have the same knowledge. Think about it. Lemme tell you something. In school, some people had to read a lot of books to know stuff and get good grades. I got good grades just from listening in class. .But wait, there's more! Having more knowledge doesn't really make you smarter. EEspecially (yes, I said it with two E) if people have too much trust on their knowledge, which is a very dumb thing to do. When I was little, like 6 years old, I once was talking with my friend and I said that I thought lightning could break rocks. But he just went out telling others that lightning breaks rock. And actually, the same thing happens a lot with science. They suggest something and you see people certifying it as fact. The smartest scientists are always reminding others that you can never be too certain of anything. The less smart people are constantly forgetting it. .Now, you know what will make you smarter? Puzzles, and conversations, and experience. And analyzing things. And the more variety, the better. Recently, I started learning capoeira, and I find it to be a great physical and mental challenge.

I can’t say for sure that reading makes people smarter, but it does improve your brain in one way or another. I recently read an article from Book Riot listing down what improves in your brain when you read: crystallised intelligence (which refers to the hard facts you know), fluid intelligence (how you solve problems, detect patterns, and how you understand and summarise crystallised intelligence), emotional intelligence (your empathy), and your brain connectivity.  When you read, you will acquire crystallised intelligence—or factual knowledge. These are the figures, data, and facts you pick up from textbooks, encyclopaedias, and other similar resources. The more you read, the more you will add to your bank of information. When you read, you improve your fluid intelligence as well. Readers develop the ability to spot patterns and establish connections quickly since they repeatedly need to understand what they read; consequently, reading hones their analytical and critical skills. Reading also improves one’s communication skills. When you read, you expose yourself to different words and different expressions. Reading teaches you how to use these words and expressions more correctly and more effectively. It also boosts your memory; when you read, you’re actually training your brain to retain the ideas you’re picking up. Third, reading improves your emotional intelligence, too. There’s actually a study by two psychologists in 2013 that revealed that people who read fiction identified other people’s emotions better than those who don’t. The study also revealed that this is because “the same psychological processes are used to navigate fiction and real relationships.” Lastly, reading increases your brain connectivity. There’s a study conducted at Emory University that discovered that reading also engages with the part of the brain that handles movement and sensation, aside from the portions that handle language. After having the participants read the novel Pompeii by Robert Harris, the researchers discovered that their brain’s language centre as well as the part that handles movement and physical feelings remained enhanced. Now that you’ve started, why don’t you go further and jump into these awesome reads? Yes most definitely. Keep in mind that I use a broader definition of smart than pure intelligence. I define smart as being effective in achieving your goals in a given environment.  Environments could run the gamut from arguing a point in class or work, managing a team to deliver a software product, solve math problems in grad school, or play a symphony.  As an added dimension, there is smart in a narrow context versus smart in a wide variety of situations or even novel situations. Ultimately it comes down to effectiveness. You could be a 12 year old with an IQ of 160, and, while yes you may be brilliant, I probably wouldn't want you working on my software product.  A lot of the problems we face are termed "wicked problems." They have no clear solution, have a multitude of pros and cons, and affect a myriad of stakeholders all of whom may each have a different perspective. With such problems, no one person can have all the answers, rather different perspectives and insights need to be generated, combined, and implemented in order to come up with a workable solution.   I'd argue that most important problems that an organization, a community, or a nation faces are wicked problems. Thus this brings us to smartness. To be effective in such situations requires a broad swath of knowledge and the ability to quickly understand and integrate different perspectives. It requires a certain agility to link up diverse concepts from different fields and see parallels.  And how do you do this?  By reading a wide variety of hard materials and an in-depth study of a variety of fields.

Yes. TV and social media (not Quora!) “dumb you down,” because they require so little attention and are not truly stimulating your mind. I think reading is one of the only cures. Reading—especially nonfiction—can teach you about topics that never occurred to you and expand your innate intelligence. You may not think like a scientist, but read some bio-psych and your brain can open up to embrace different pathways that are natural to the author. A lot of fiction is art. Art can cleanse the soul and offer you great beauty and escape. The most striking advantage of reading is exposure to WORDS. You can vastly improve your writing and speaking abilities—not by just becoming more informed or interesting—but by increasing your vocabulary. Many words I wouldn’t know if I had not learned them through reading. You may have to look them up for pronunciation! I don’t read enough, but I do try to read every night before sleeping—just to clean my brain out, interrupt my anxious thoughts, and to set my subconscious free to dream up what I have to do the next day. I don’t really understand this magic trick reading plays on consciousness, but I have faith and just believe.

Reading will not change your innate intelligence. Intelligence is related to the amount of gray matter in certain areas of the brain. That’s a matter of genetics and nurture as a baby and child, when your brain is physically growing. Human Intelligence Determined By Volume And Location Of Gray Matter Tissue In Brain Reading anything will make you more knowledgeable. Reading somethings will make you more knowledgeable than reading other things. Reading people Magazine isn’t going to have the same effect as reading Orwell or well written non fiction. Though Though there is nothing wrong with reading some garbage on occasion, I do. I also like watching some TV sometimes. You will gain vocabulary and an understanding of the meanings of words by reading. Sometimes word meanings are slightly nuanced and if you just study them in isolation, you end up miss using them or using them in a way that comes off awkwardly. You may be intelligent if you do that, but people won’t see you as intelligent. They see you as pompous, verbose, or just plain full of yourself. Reading nonfiction will make you more knowledgeable about the subjects you may be intelligent if you do that, but people won’t see you as intelligent. They see you as pompous, verbose, or just plain full of yourself you read about. If you’re reading nonfiction about history, you’ll be knowledgeable about that, but you may not be knowledgeable about other non-fiction topics, for example, science. If I you’re reading fiction, you will become more knowledgeable about that genre. I’ve read all of John Steinbeck‘s works. I’m knowledgeable about his writing. Good fiction can give you an understanding of the human experience, something that nonfiction may or may not be able to do.A book about wild birds in a certain geographical area will not give you insight into the human experience. A book about sociology might, but it would be specific to the nonfiction topic it covers. Pick up a book, any book, and read it. It’s better than reading Quora answers. It’s definitely better than watching TV or a Vlog. Regardless of what you read, you’ll be smarter than if you don’t read at all.

Not necessarily, but it certainly makes you more knowledgeable than the person who doesn’t read! Reading only makes you smarter if you absorb what you read and then utilise it. There is an old saying that Knowledge is Power, but it really isn’t. the real power comes from applied knowledge! This means that you can be as knowledgeable as you can be, but if you never put that knowledge to any use, if your life and skills are not really enhanced by it, you would be no more smarter or capable, despite what you might know. Again, our chosen books tell a lot about us, often revealing far more about our passions in life that we might openly admit. For example, if you are not reading anything it says volumes about your own desire to self-educate, to learn, and to raise your development standards. Reading books is a sign of being alive, of being intelligent and being curious. Thus an absence of books would say more about you in a social gathering than whatever you actually say. Even if you do not become any smarter, reading is more likely to do the following for you: Improves and widens your vocabulary. You will learn far more words, and gain great expressive fluency, through the information relating to places, things, people, and ideas.Widens your experience of your world. Books are very informative, and offer a opportunities to escape to unknown places, sharing unknown cultures, and experiencing new sensations. The imagination can work very powerfully with a good book.Improves your personal expression. Reading regularly will improve your own expression and the choices you have in expressing yourself to whatever audience is necessary. It is also likely to give you greater confidence in dealing with others.Appreciates other viewpoints, because reading exposes us to a wider variety of ideas and contexts.Gives you something to share with others. Reading gives us shared experiences with which we can make friends, build friendships, develop interests and have common points of conversation and discussions.Increases your chances of success. "Leaders are readers", as one writer said, which makes reading essential to achievement, especially relating to elements that are of relevance to your goals, vision and purpose. The more you read, the more your knowledge will grow, the more you will be exposed to similar and alternate views, the more you will identify allies and rivals, opportunities and possibilities. Furthermore, as you read, the more confident you will feel in achieving your aims through increased knowledge of how to bring them to life.In a nutshell, books can make you smarter, but there is no guarantee of that. It all depends on how you utilise what you read. However, one thing is certain: without constant reading you cannot build your vocabulary, you are dependent upon old and outdated knowledge to guide you, and you will be limited in your thoughts and intellect. In short, not reading very much turns us into fossils being left behind by the rushing tide of time, events, new expressions, and new innovations.

Reading is the most important skill you can have. More important than IQ. More important than math. There is simply no faster way to learn something. I love Khan Academy, but I have no patience for videos. Raising the speed doesn’t help me. Lectures don’t help me. I learn the same way I learn everything and that is reading. I got into speed reading (basically reading with your eyes, and not subvocalizing) when I was studying for the SAT. It changed everything. There’s always some argument about how increasing speed means you decrease comprehension. Well then read slower. But over time you will improve. It just happens. It is inevitable. I teach it to all of my students because critical reading passages are on every standardized test and reading is something you simply cannot escape in life. Fortunately, now, we have resources like spreeder. Considering the fact that I read nonstop from when I wake to when I sleep and have been for the better half of my life, I used spreeder to clock my reading speed. I can do it in front of anyone. I have them pick some random passage and copy and paste it into spreeder, I set the chunk size to 6 words, and I have the speed 5000 wpm. Yes, I can read that. I can spot typo’s on pages faster than anyone I know. I read automatically. It’s always on. And yes, you can read that fast too. — My study method for example the MCAT, involves me using a minimum of three different prep books from different companies, and an open window for google image search. I read from all of these sources as I take my notes. I prefer to take my time to absorb the information. But I’ve had times where I procrastinated so much I’d read 600 pages of a not too dense textbook and score pretty well on an exam. — This is a top speed. I don’t read everything this fast. For instance, novels I like to subvocalize and take my time. Honestly, stop following all of the quora shit on IQ’s. I’ve just stopped following that stuff myself. Nothing is as important as reading.

No. Reading more will make you a less ignorant person, not smarter-- But people will find it easier to assume that you are smarter.  Smart is just another synonym for intelligent. Your intelligence is mostly based on your health, and your genetics. People tend to mis-correlate high intelligence with high levels of knowledge. Being noticeably knowledgable in a subject will make people assume that you are very intelligent. But this is a false assumption.  There are plenty of people with average intelligences that are more knowledgable in subjects than people with superior IQ's. I am an intelligent person, but I know nothing about being an accountant-- If you make me and an accountant with an average IQ take the same test on finance, that accountant is going to kick my butt at that test. Not because they are smarter, but because they know more.  That being said, reading will make you less ignorant, and if you are already intelligent you will have more information at hand to utilize at your leisure. It's also a lot easier to draw more insightful conclusions when you have more information.  Reading more will provide you with tools that will be invaluable regardless of intelligence, but it will also amplify your ability to apply your pre-established intelligence.

Well that depends. It certainly can expand ones knowledge in new areas. Reading the classics like Dostoevsky, Camus etc also have incredible wisdom and life advice. However reading something like Thus Spake Zarathustra will not bring you new knowledge in the same way that reading an algebra text book will. Most philosophy books are quite difficult so to really gain knowledge the best way I've found is this formula Read a brief synopsis of the book so you understand what is the message this person is trying to convey.Read the book once through all the way, do it section by section and after each section write a brief outline of what the key message is. While reading it highlight the things you don't understand or that don't make sense in one color, and the things that do make sense and that you think are important in another color. Try to read it through very naturally though, don't like take notes on each bit.Then go over what you've written down and use the help of a professor or the internet etc to try and clarify what you know and don't know. This means finding the best possible explanation of the book, Stanford philosophy is a great resource. Make sure you Vet your source and don't rely on a random internet person or even quora unless it's an expert who answers.Re-read the book, and this time do a comprehensive write up of each section etc. the write up should be done with the idea that your teaching this material to someone else, so write it out as if your about to give a lecture to a 101 class on this book. This will be very time consuming and could take weeks if you are reading it in your spare time.Finally put everything else away and just read the book in a very natural way as if it was a fiction novel. When reading take the point of view that "this is a human being trying to communicate a message about life to another human being." Since this is sort of vague/high-level it helps you not get bogged down by details or confusing sentences.Then lastly use whatever resources you can to clarify what the book is about. If there is any remaining issue.If you do this while reading Plato, Aristotle, Kant, Hume, Hegel, Nietzsche, Descartes, Aquinas, Kierkegaard, Sartre, etc you'll be in great shape. (The above list is ONLY WESTERN PHILOSOPHERS, that means anything frkm Asia, Africa, Asia Minor etc is not included, and there are some incredible philosophers who should be included during your reading, however it is sometimes easier to start with western philosophers as they are more relatable and the translations of their work is more fluid.)

Story Time. A guy named ‘Arun’ went to his guru for clearing his doubts. Arun : Guru, why do we read books ? Guru : To purify our brain and gain knowledge. Arun : But, i don’t remember a word from the first book i read. Guru : You do. Arun : How? I don’t understand. Guru : Okay. Go and fill a glass half with sand. Arun went and filled the glass with sand. He came back and gave the glass to his Guru. Guru: Now pour the water up to the brim of the glass Arun did as his guru said. After filling water he gave the glass to his guru. Guru just put the glass upside down. A good amount of sand got removed with water. Arun : Guru, what did you do ? Guru : See Arun, the sand in the glass represents the bad/dirty things in your mind and the water in the glass represents the knowledge. If you read book regularly then you can clean your mind regularly otherwise one day you are going to be just sand and dirt. Reading doesn’t make you a smarter person but it helps you understand life better .

I think reading is one of the more productive activities you can do. By reading anything, even mass-produced fantasy or crime books, you`re cultivating an ability to concentrate over extended periods of time. Having this ability is becoming ever rarer in a world of vines, on-demand news, clickbaits, memes and listed entries (Here are 10 methods to learn ANY language in just one month, etc..).There is a quote that stuck with me from the movie/book Fight Club, I transcribe: “when people think you`re dying they really listen to you, instead of just waiting for their turn to speak”. As the author of many books on how to “win friends”, Carnegie noted that the most used word in the average phone conversation was “I”. The point of both these quotes is to illustrate that all of us are the main person in the world in our own minds. When you`re reading a book, you`re really getting into the mind and perspective of another person. For as long as it takes to read the book, you`re in someone else`s shoes. If you read War and Peace you will get a better understanding of the russian mentality, if you read Lolita you might find yourself sympathizing with a pedophile, if you read The Great Gatsby you`ll get an idea of the decadence of rich-people life in the 20s.. and so on. You`ll realize there are almost endless amounts of cultures, societies and mentalities out there, and for every book you read you`ll be able to understand just a bit more the complex layers of meaning around you.Whatever you read you`re expanding your vocabulary, and for every new word you learn, there is a new way of expressing a thought or arguing a point. Being the owner of a large vocabulary means you will find it easier to use the written word to your advantage, and you won`t be as afraid to start the process of writing. This is important in many respects. Just think how nice it would be to always have well-written resumes, job applications, invitations, letters and speeches.

The Major Intellectual Benefits of Reading All these years, the world has been abuzz with plenty of reasons as to why it is essential for people to develop and maintain a healthy habit of reading. But how does it exactly benefit the human mind? It expands your vocabulary. Reading does significantly expand your vocabulary in ways that you may not notice right away. It exposes you to and lets you uncover the context of the words that you’ve probably never heard of before. Reading compels you to look up the meaning of the words you’ve just read, hence as you go further along, the more the sentences make sense to you than before you began reading them. It improves your communication skills. This goes hand in hand with vocabulary: the more you read, the more words you have available in your frame of reference to use in everyday conversations. Reading teaches you new words and new ways to use the words more correctly when constructing sentences in your mind. It develops your analytical skills. A research conducted by Dr. Anne E. Cunningham, professor of psychology in the University of Berkeley in California, shows that readers are seen to have a greater general knowledge and are able to spot patterns a lot quicker. The more patterns you spot, the more developed your analytical skills become. It is an effective memory booster. Reading and memory are two interrelated concepts. When you read, you are more of training your brain to retain the ideas and words you are reading, which eventually helps boost your memory.

In one word, YES! Reading can make you a smarter person, but it entirely depends on what you are reading. If you are reading a book that can teach you something, then yes you will definitely become a smarter person. Let me explain. Connect the dots When you read, you start to form connections in the back of your brain. I like to call this “connecting the dots”. When you read something, you get ideas. The more you read, the more ideas you get. These ideas can be some tips or entire concepts. When you start connecting those ideas together (just like connecting two dots with a line), you start understanding things better. You start to see things differently. You see and understand the big picture. This helps you become a much wiser and smarter person. Broaden your perspective or mind When you read books in various categories, you start to see things from different point of views. The more you understand these viewpoints, the better you see things that others miss out, and the smarter you get. Grow your knowledge Reading books provides you with huge amount of knowledge. Knowledge that not only makes you look smarter, but when put to good use will help you live the life of your dreams. Unlimited potential Reading is the best habit there is. But you need to be careful about what you are reading. Choose the books that are right for you and you will keep getting smarter and smarter everyday. There are no limits to your mind’s potential, except those you set for yourself. When you read, those limits break and your mind’s potential is set free. A free mind is much more powerful and smarter. So start reading books and get smarter everyday. See you in the book club!

response.answer_text: Reading allows you to incorporate information and experience (whether fictional or real) that you would not have had if you had never opened any book.  It allows you access to the minds of others from distant times and places.  It teaches you that this modern world was not always here, and that people thought in other ways.  It places you in a situation of danger and allows you to practice what reactions you might have were you in that character's place, encourages you to pit your mind against the detective to solve the mystery, see what it takes to be an astronaut, learn how devastating the Civil War was, or how wonderful it was to be present at the founding of our country, to ponder thoughts from philosophers to janitors about ultimate issues of life, death, God, and evil.  A book is not only the best time machine, but also the best movie theater (your mind produces better special effects than any CGI).  The richness that reading adds to life is indispensable.   TV is inferior for two reasons:  you are seeing on the TV screen something that the director sees and formulates for you.  And what you see is inherently deceptive, because you believe the images you see ("seeing is believing," after all!  Isn't it?  Not necessarily.)  A television program is expensive to produce, and fewer people can get one produced and shown. Sure, it's fun, and more gratifying immediately, but reading is ultimately more powerful because it allows you to use your mind rather than passively accepting the products of someone else's mind.

Reading has these benefits: First thing: reading doesn't make you smart. It makes you wise. When you read, you are deciphering the meaning/interpretation of every word, which means you are making an effort to get a grip on something. And when you make an effort, the outcome of that effort stays with you forever. When you read, you are opening up your mind to opinions. When you open up, it means your mind has more space and hence more power to process. Reading teaches you how language can be used to convey feelings/expressions/convictions. To read is to access someone else's mind. You can understand the inclinations of a person through his/her writings. Reading increases patience. Because it takes time to understand anything in life. Unlike writing, reading can't be copied. Reading is the only proof that you are literate. Helping others to read is the only proof that you're educated and useful.Reading is the only way through which you can read this.

To really answer this question let's define the two things that we are trying to equate. Smartness. Smart can mean anything from well-dressed to street-savvy. For this discussion we can limit its scope to "wiser than earlier", which makes it a personal growth journey. (Worth pursuing).'Reading' - So the question is - reading what? Let's classify reading sources in general and their ability to influence the ‘Smartness’ that we chose in (1).Here are the different things we generally tend to read and how I think they fare in achieving (1).Non-fiction: Genuine Experiences of remarkable people who are humble enough to tell them as close to the truth as they can. (These are immensely useful. Some great reads I found are: Barefoot Coach by Paddy Upton, Dreams From My Father by Barack Obama, Surely You're Joking My Feynman, The Stories of My Experiments with Truth by MK Gandhi, Open by Andre Agassi)(Humble) Smartness tip: Make your own notes on these and use those as guides.Non-fiction: Newspaper stories which are presented as non-fiction but we don't know the motivations and internal biases of the people writing them. Sometimes the shroud of this is more dangerous than openly dishonest autobiographies.Smartness tip: Take them as wonderful hypotheses and to better your skills of weaning out good sources from the bad. Over time once you have established your own sources you trust, these can be used as great sources of general knowledge and awareness of the world around you.Non-fiction: Ideas that are derived from people's, experiments, theories and so on. These make for great reading but you need to think about them exactly for what they are - ideas and not always truths. Smartness tip: Use these for trying out things for yourself and see what works for you.Non-fiction: Compilations of deep research of measurable and factually verifiable phenomenon. These, especially when well-narrated can really help you not just know interesting things but to also remember them. Smartness tip: Might want to read these multiple times!  (Some great reads in this category: Sapiens, A Short History of Nearly Everything, Genome, The Emperor of All MaladiesFiction - Well written, great language (any language)These are like music to the mind. They tease your imagination and spread pixie dust on the daily grind of life. "Oh the places you will go!" like one wonderful book title says, is true with these. Classics even act as passive teachers, you will find that if you read things that are well-written, what you write will also subtly get better. They give you a portkey that you can lose yourself into. Great reads: So many but try to explore great writers from your own language as well. Smart Tip: At Choose To Thinq we try to read random things without thinking too much. Really helps staying curious.Enjoy the journey!

It probably doesn’t help to increase your basic IQ but it can make you more effectively intelligent. A person who has a high IQ but plays video games all day is not going to be effective at much of anything other than winning video games. By contrast a person with lower basic intelligence who reads a lot may well hone skills that are useful in a wide variety of arenas. Reading can provide you with information that you can’t easily acquire from direct experience, and probably helps to create greater emotional intelligence. Reading also helps us become better writers and to express ourselves more clearly and cogently. Your basic IQ is important. Very smart people can do things that those with lower IQs cannot. But at the end of the day you have to work with what you have, and in most areas of life it’s how you use your native intelligence that’s crucial. For that reading can be important, indeed essential.

I must not say that reading makes you smarter in every way but I must say this that it makes you smarter in some specific ways. When it comes to crystallized intelligence, fluid intelligence, emotional intelligence and brain connectivity, reading certainly plays an important role. Now, let me explain all these four things separately :- Crystallized Intelligence:- It's all about factual informations and knowledge that a person posses. And I feel that reading certainly enhances one’s information base.Fluid Intelligence:- It involves problem solving abilities, pattern detection ability and ability to understand things in totality.Emotional Intelligence:- It's a person's ability to understand what others think and feel.Brain Connectivity:- It is the ability of brain to associate different facets in order to feel more human.Now coming to the question whether reading makes smart or not?. Since, now we know that reading enhancing ones ability in terms of crystallized intelligence, fluid intelligence, emotional intelligence and brain connectivity. Let me discuss all these outcomes of reading individually, which may give is some clue about whether reading making us intelligent and smart or dumb. Crystallized intelligence, means informations and data, I really don't think that a person who has more information and data is smart, so for me a person who poses crystallized intelligence is not necessarily smart. Reading and fluid intelligence have a reciprocal relationship; reading trains people’s brains to better detect more meaningful patterns and as people make these connections, they better understand what they read. What's the conclusion here is, you have to be smart enough to understand the things which creates difference. people who read fiction are significantly better at identifying other people’s emotions because “the same psychological processes are used to navigate fiction and real relationships. Therefore, fictional studies will make people more human means in my opinion more smart. Since I have discussed about the outcomes of reading and after analysing all these outcomes one by one, it must be said that one can not define a person's smartness on the basis of how diverse his or her reading is?. Then suddenly my mind asked, so what makes a person smart then ?. What SMART exactly stands for?, I will call a person smart if he has patience, delligence, and determination, because you will be called smart only when you have achieved something significant. And we all know that Reading requires all three. That means, you can develop all those qualities which required to be successful while reading. Therefore, there is no doubt that reading books make people smart. Jai Hind

Intelligence— what it is, and what it isn’t— is actually one of my favorite topics. So I may go on a bit. Intelligence, for starters, is a baseline thing. Though it shouldn’t be oversimplified, it’s definitely still a baseline thing. What you’re born with, you’re born with. It can be diminished in any number of ways, such as trauma or substance abuse or, really, even just a horrible life as a child. And only very rarely, such as in the case of Daniel Tammet, is it likely to improve. It’s analogous to the spending limit a bank places on your credit card. You can only spend what you’ve been predetermined to have. Where the cheese starts sliding off the cracker on this, is our tendency to fail to note that there are many different kinds of intelligence. If someone writes well, or perhaps performs maths well, they tend to get ranked as intelligent. But the guy out on the green? or on the basketball court? He tends to have his unique form of intelligence overlooked. In actuality, there’s a specific kind of intelligence known as kinesthetics which makes his ability what it is. He’s not just faster or stronger than his mates, though obviously that helps. The team athlete is at all times bombarded with the need to make quick decisions on the move. And those decisions invariably involve navigating in and through other things (and people) which, like him, are in motion. In a nutshell, if he’s good, he’s outsmarting everybody. Science has nailed down at least eleven distinct forms of intelligence. Musicality is another one. You’re born with it or you’re not. And even if you’ve got it, well, how much of it? And that’s where things get interesting. Each form of intelligence comes in all sizes. Some people can carry a tune, but not much more. Others can write symphonies. Some can keep a beat. Or someone like Phil Collins can sing one rhythmic line while pounding out an entirely different one with his hands and his feet. At the end of it all, this makes each individual remarkably unique. Each person is likely to have any number of the different kinds of intelligence. Let’s say I have five of them— a, b, c, d, and e. But let’s say someone else has the same five. Are we the same? No to the no. On scales one to ten, my five might rank 7, 4, 6, 8, 3. His might rank 5, 9, 9, 1, 5. Same intelligences, but a completely different landscape, even if we ignore the inevitable decimal places. It’s this blending of the different kinds of intelligence, all depending on their levels, which makes each of us so unlike each other. It is human nature to compare ourselves to each other, and to try to figure how we size up. Plus we live in a world that pushes us pretty hard in that direction. I encourage people to recognize that their value isn’t to be based on where they rank as, say, a wordsmith or a number cruncher. Our value, I believe, is something more of a fingerprint. I know before I open my mouth that the person I’m talking to is literally unlike anyone else. I’ve done the math. The number of possible configurations far outpaces the number of people on the planet, or even the number it could hold. So, to the question. Does reading make us more intelligent? Much depends on who’s doing the reading and, in truth, what they’re reading. But if growth occurs, is it really “intelligence” that’s growing? No. Knowledge may grow. But so may delusion. If one digests what is factual and true, knowledge legitimately grows. If one digests what it false, though does not see it as false, knowledge diminishes. Yet knowledge, is utterly key to the development of wisdom. Reading can play a role in that. Or it can play a role in making us just the opposite of wise. We’ll know more words. We’ll perhaps become better at putting a strong sentence together. So on the face of things, as far as anyone can tell at a glance, we’ve become “smarter.” And by smarter, yes, we mean more able, which not at all is the same as more intelligent. But if our becoming stronger is not also our becoming wiser, we’re kidding not only the observer but even ourselves. Reading comes with no such assurances. Those assurances have to come from an entirely different place. Intelligence is a big deal. Heart is a bigger one. The heart is the neck that turns the head. What do you read and why?

I am glad that some fellow readers have come up with some exceptional answers to this question. In my point of view, reading plays an important role in improving any person’s intellect. Various researches have shown that the more one reads, the easier it is to make a quick judgment. So in short, reading does make you a smarter person. Definitely. As a toddler, my mother would teach me to read small words after every meal. Then, in kindergarten, I discovered the joy of reading books myself for fun. Throughout most of my childhood, I was not allowed to watch tv, play video/computer games, or have playdates. Pretty much all of my time outside of school was spent reading. It was like that for me all the way until high school. Now, I’m a bit smarter than my peers. I’m also more creative, handier, and better at writing and proofreading. All of this because I went through books like they were water, starting with one each week in kindergarten, and getting to the point where, in 7th grade, I could read 7 books in a single weekend. In short, if you read enough, you will become smarter.

The answer must be carefully addressed, because in one scenario, what you use as “educational books” may not be the best books to “educate” yourself with. You will find it difficult to educate yourself with books that are largely rhetorical. Neither will reading novels “educate” you as well as nonfiction books will “educate” you. As a general answer, it is true that “reading enough educational books” can offer you the knowledge you seek. However, it is also a fact that you could read many books over a period of many years and do little more than study things that completely confuse you. This is entirely possible because there is an abundance of books that qualify as “educational books” which are published every year, and it constitutes a body of literature which is not very helpful at all. Some “educational books” will make you smarter and some will not, and that is why the question must be answered carefully. Also to be taken into consideration is your reading ability, your reading vocabulary, your awareness of an Academic Vocabulary and the Academic Word List and your familiarity with Stative Verbs and their Noun Forms or the Stative Nouns and their Verb Forms. “Stative Verbs” are verbs which correspond with expressing feelings and ideas (Mental Actions). “Stative Nouns” are nouns which correspond with feelings and ideas (Mental Objects). There is a culture war in full swing and in the culture war it is often the strategy of some “educational books” and their authors to encourage the use of Physical Verbs and Physical Nouns and to discourage the use of Mental Verbs and Mental Nouns. However, if you want to avoid the mental manipulation in those books, you will need to develop a knowledge of Mental Verbs (Stative Verbs) and Mental Nouns (Stative Nouns) which are called Nominalizations. You will not be actually “smart” until you can write sentences which use an Academic Vocabulary. I can show you a kind of “shortcut” and the short cut is something you can print out as a guide for some of your study. It is called a “Common Book” or a “Commonplace Book”. It contains some basic information regarding educational subjects for study. Here is where you will find that on www.Quora.com: Bruce R. Bain's answer to Is one textbook per topic enough? As you learn things which are “educational” you should write it in a notebook and begin making your own “Common Book”.  So far, what I suggest for you still offers you a broad spectrum of possibilities. Try as I might to narrow your “educational” reading to something manageable, there is so much “educational” to know that you can easily feel discouraged and depressed. Therefore, I suggest that you focus on developing an Academic Vocabulary, because that will give you the power to understand “educational books” and will also give you the power to write about “educational” subjects. So I suggest you educate yourself about the English Language, and particularly the language that goes beyond the vocabulary associated with fiction books. (This does not mean you should not read fiction books for fun. You certainly should read for fun, but you should prepare yourself to communicate in what is called the real world.) See on www.quora.com Bruce R. Bain's answer to How do I improve my English?

Alright, I see elements in your question that require attention: 1. reading 2. make 3. intelligent. Reading is a means of acquiring information. So, are you asking about reading specifically or about information in general? Because someone can be a genius without reading a book his entire life, if he listens to that information, or learns it through experience, or has it downloaded to his brain through some futuristic device we are yet to invent. Regardless of the means, information is what intelligence uses as material, without information there is no process to manipulate that information. It just can’t exist one without the other.Make - it is known already, intelligence is stable across life, generally. It changes very slowly, and only in one direction - down. As we age, we are getting more stupid, i.e. we lose capability to learn and to adapt as we get older, but we compensate that by becoming more experienced and more educated. It’s like solving same problem several times, at some point you will do it a lot more efficiently than someone smarter that does it first time. Reading books, or, becoming more experienced, won’t make you smarter, but it can definitely help become wiser.Intelligent? do you mean the actual intelligence? the capacity to solve problems and to learn fast and to adapt and to understand complex ideas? Or do you mean educated? These are different things. Intelligence is what helps someone be efficient at tackling new information, new environment, but if one lives in a stable environment, he can invest some time in adapting, and become competent in whatever he does there, as long as things are repetitive enough(not dynamic).So, the key word is competence. Whatever is your intellect now, it will never go up, so don’t think about it too much. Just find your spot in this life, become competent and educated in that field of yours, and you will be more efficient than smart people that are just passing by(with some exceptions of course), so as long as you will be useful to your community in that way, you’ll have at least one extra good thing in your life.

Not necessarily. “When we read, another person thinks for us: we merely repeat his mental process. It is the same as the pupil, in learning to write, following with his pen the lines that have been penciled by the teacher. Accordingly, in reading, the work of thinking is, for the greater part, done for us. This is why we are consciously relieved when we turn to reading after being occupied with our own thoughts. But, in reading, our head is, however, really only the arena of some one else’s thoughts. And so it happens that the person who reads a great deal — that is to say, almost the whole day, and recreates himself by spending the intervals in thoughtless diversion, gradually loses the ability to think for himself; just as a man who is always riding at last forgets how to walk. Such, however, is the case with many men of learning: they have read themselves stupid. For to read in every spare moment, and to read constantly, is more paralyzing to the mind than constant manual work, which, at any rate, allows one to follow one’s own thoughts.” -Schopenhauer

Books have the ability to capture vivid worlds of imagination, entire lifetimes of incredible people, the story of the universe ( a short history of nearly everything gives a fast paced attempt at the comprehensive history of human scientific discovery across geology, physics, chemistry, biology — science), knowledge, stories, the basis of religion, ceremony. Nearly 1200 years ago, Japanese swords reached a level of perfection on par with today’s most advanced steel manufacture. Interestingly enough, people at the time hadn’t the slightest idea about the science of steel; they had no tools or concept for measuring carbon content and their method of determining proper metal temperatures involved comparing the sword’s glowing metal to that of the early morning sun. Not so long ago, knowledge wasn’t captured in the form of written words, but passed by word of mouth, tradition, ceremony, master to apprentice and other such inaccessible means. Books and indeed the written word (with varying degrees of success) are somewhat permanent and immutable records which can contain access to vast worlds of knowledge far beyond the consumption capacity of a single person.

Well, that largely depends on what you mean by “smarter”. Reading books does not increase your IQ (as someone noted in an earlier answer there is no real known way to do that). Although, ones IQ is really only a small piece of a much larger puzzle. It does increase ones knowledge and brain power though. Many people have noted that it depends on what you read. That is certainly true. Books that really make you think, or challenge what you think you know are going to have a greater impact than books that do not. However, I would argue that HOW you read is equally as important (irrespective of WHAT you are actually reading). Even reading “trashy” novels can be done critically, which will provide you a greater benefit than simply reading a quality book more passively. Ask yourself questions as you read. Do you agree with what the protagonist did? What do you think was the motivation of the antagonist? Was there a better option that could have been chosen? Why did the author choose this path? How would I react in this situation? How does this jive with my understanding of the world? Why do I feel the way I do about this character? Engaging with books in this manner is going to bring out far more benefit than simply reading a book, and will increase your ability to think and reason, which I think are a much better measure of “smartness” than simple IQ.

Tl;dr: No To give a comprehensive answer, I would like to go in depth. Reading books alone won’t make a person smart or intelligent, what really matters is how you implement the lessons you get from the book into your own life. I have seen so many people reading books on how to get productive and spending days to go through hundreds of pages only leading to nothing. There was this valuable lesson I learnt while I was learning a new language. Someone in a video said “Knowledge is something if you don’t use it you will eventually lose it” So if you read books only for the sake of fun or hobby without getting the gist of what that book is conveying to you and without using tht knowledge that book is as good as being unread. For me personally the smartest person would be the one who does something with the knowledge he gets from the book . It can be anything from changing your view on life , motivating you to achieve your goal or even sharing your experience of the book with someone. This is the kind of person I regard as Smart. Instead of a person who has this humongous library, and only gloats about the no of books he has read. I hope this helps.

Reading CAN make you a more educated person. Some say it can make you a more empathetic person. It takes more involvement from the brain than watching TV or film, so it’s probably better for you in some ways. Reading can stoke your curiosity, it can help you be more imaginative, but none of these are granted just from reading. Reading doesn’t help much if it doesn’t challenge you on some level. To help make you “smarter,” which is a good all-encompassing term for it, you need to run into words you don’t know, ideas you haven’t engaged with, experiences you haven’t had, or perspectives you haven’t considered. You need to be ready to think critically about what you read, decide if you’re going to accept it or not, and why. You also need to have fun with it, because otherwise it doesn’t stick. Just reading a few lines doesn’t make you smarter. Incorporating the new information you receive into your daily life does.

Sort of. Sometimes. But not always. A couple of different activities take place when we read: We sometimes learn new information. We sometimes get a repeat of information we already have. And sometimes we trigger new and novel thoughts as a composite of other thoughts due to the reading. An example would be you read something, then start thinking about something else other than what you just read, but slightly connected. The simple act of reading, doesn’t make you smarter by itself, but it does make you better at reading. which you might then use to read more often or longer, and depending on what you ar reading, may learn new things. Smarter is used to describe different abilities that are grouped together. One is rote memory. One is understanding. A third is the creation of new ideas. But it all starts with the initial knowledge that we are picking up.

Yes. Reading and the love of reading should be developed at an early age. I have a button from my local library that says, "Readers are Leaders". So true. As a five year old child, my godmother sat me on her lap, and started teaching me to read from the Holy Bible. Big, hard to pronounce words. In first grade, I was introduced to the color-coded Weekly Readers series. I basically blew through them, because they were so much easier to read and understand than the Bible. I've had a library card (not the same one) for almost 60 years. I don't necessarily know if reading made me "smarter", but it certainly opened up whole new worlds of understanding and knowledge.

yes reading most definitely opens your mind, allows in educated opinon, and changes your knowledge and intellect.. for instance i am currently reading about real economics, money, fraud, secrecy juristictions, banking and politics.. i am quite mathematical, and a computer expert, but i have never really read up on such matters. i must admit my mind is totally blown, and my entire view of politics, everyday people, the world economy has been totally shattered and rebuilt. like henry ford once said. It is well enough that people of the nation do not understand our banking and monetary system... for if they did, I believe there would be a revolution before tomorrow morning. i now feel exactly the same way and have numerous reasons to feel that way. so books have opened me up to many truths that had previously eluded me; not only that, but it has made me panic about the fact that, general society as a whole do not know what i now do know. I would actually go as far as saying the stack of books i am currently reading have changed my entire life, my entire outlook, my entire approach, and will in turn change the lives of my children, all for the better. so yes reading makes you smarter.

Reading inherently does not make you smarter. It’s being able to take what you read and apply it to outside situations or form opinions of your own based on the evidence you collected from reading that makes you smart. If you’ve seen the movie “Good Will Hunting” then you’ll see what I mean during the bar scene in which Will tells off an arrogant jerk in front of Skylar. The jerk basically regurgitates what he read but is unable to form his own opinions. He undoubtedly read but he didn’t get any smarter from it as he did not strive to understand it. In conclusion, reading is a tool that can help you but it will not solely make you smarter. Just my two cents.
