response.answer_text: TLDR : YES  The data reported herein appear to indicate that these theorists could well bewrong in this conclusion. If “smarter” means having a larger vocabulary andmore world knowledge in addition to the abstract reasoning skills encompassedwithin the concept of intelligence, as it does in most laymen’s definitions ofintelligence (Stanovich, 1989; Sternberg, 1990)’ then reading may we16 makepeople smarter. Certainly our data demonstrate time and again that print exposureis associated with vocabulary, general knowledge, and verbal skills even aftercontrolling for abstract reasoning abilities (as measured by such indicators as theRaven). Although nothing can turn our correlational data into true experimentalfindings, the converging patterns of relationships-most importantly the indicationthat reading habits predict growth in verbal abilities in longitudinal investigations(see Tables V and VI; Anderson et al., 1988; Juel, 1988)-certainlyimply a role for reading experience in a comprehensive theory of cognitivegrowth (its role is at least as well supported as many other mechanisms that haveattained popularity in developmental psychology).  Reference : Does Reading Make You Smarter? Literacy and the Development of Verbal Intelligence - p 170

This seems like an obviously easy question to answer. Reading does make people in general smarter. But how much smarter is the ultimate question? Some people read a lot, but because of low retention and low ability; they don't profit as much as others from reading the same materials. Some students in college routinely fall asleep while reading their textbooks. They fall asleep and have little to no recollection of what they’ve read--no matter how many times they attempted to read it. Some people can read something once and retain most of it. Also, they can find useful and novel ways of using the information. So two people independent of each other can do the same reading most of their life, beginning in their youth and the results will be uneven in the end. The following assertion I'm about to make is anecdotal and unverified by science as I know it, but if you're interested in something and your learning style is the reading method; your profit from reading will be higher than someone who's not interested in the same subject matter. So interest and ability contribute the most to the reading experience.

It depends on what you read. Encyclopedias are chock full of information, but I don’t think that’s what you have on your mind. Although, you can pick up certain things from almost everything you read. I used to read a lot when I was in middle school and by the time I reached high school I had a college vocabulary. I seem to recall watching a video saying reading improves your memory and ability to learn. Reading helps you grasp topics quicker and gives you little bits and pieces of information over time, but what really helps is reading challenging books. Those books that are around 900+ pages long. Those are my personal favorite. Find what genre you like and stick with that. Those who don’t like to read, just haven’t found a book that appeals to them.

Reading some things makes some people smarter. Thinking involves thinking about some subject, applying knowledge to that subject, and thinking correctly and creatively about that subject. If you read truthful, factual, and correctly argued material (including fiction), and if you remember what you read, then you can increase the knowledge available to apply to many subjects. Your reading may also increase the ways you can think about a subject. Your reading can help you avoid cognitive biases. Your reading can teach you scientific methods, mathematical models, and concepts like experimentation, development, evolution, competition, cooperation, probability distributions, degrees of certainty, statistical significance, optimization, and many more. You can use these patterns of thought in your own thinking. But there’s a danger that reading badly could make you less smart. You could read nonsense, misinformation, or only sources that confirm your biases. You could read carelessly, misremembering details or remembering only your feelings as you read. Don’t do that. Good luck.

I put most of this as an answer to one of the other answers regarding reading books and the different genres they mostly fit into. I highly suggest scifi as a way to enter the field of reading and learning. My reasons are below. Scifi doesnt merely take tired tropes and toss some ‘sciency' words on top. True scifi examines various human cultures and their ideals, taking them apart and placing them into a storyline that creates unease on the part of the reader and allows the reader to begin to parse their own related experiences. For example, Le Guin's Left Hand of Darkness. Yes, there are sciency bits and words and concepts, such as how to achieve instantaneous communication over thousands of light years and when and how that would fail, or how androgeny works, but the main thrust of the story line, as it were, is not driven by sciency bits decorating the story lines like ill placed Christmas garlands, and tired tropes. The story follows a human alpha male diplomat who is assigned to a world of mostly androgynous humanoids. I say mostly, as they are truly androgynous for the majority of the time, except they become male or female during their rare sexual ‘heats.’ This is very difficult for the protagonist, as well as for readers. How do you manuever in a society as a male, who is always a male, when most in the society see that as a biological fail, and a perversion. When most assume you are insane as sexual hormones affect your thoughts and behaviors and tolerate your presence as English kings once tolerated dwarves? How do you convince the society of anything? Much less be a diplomatic envoy? I chose le Guin and the Left Hand of Darkness, as unlike others, she also has a breathtaking soft sciences background. Her middle initial, Ursula K. le Guin, stands for Kroeber, the anthropologist who held Ishi for the last years of Ishi's life. Le Guin has a unique approach to most of her work, from young adult fiction and fantasy to some of her hard core scifi, then the majority of scifi authors. If you truly want to start learning, to pump up those IQ numbers, true scifi is the gateway ‘drug's into all other genres. Heinlein, Asimov, le Guin, Herbert, Wells, Brin, Atwood, Dick, Gibson, Mary Shelley are just a few scifi authors whom are still giants in the field, and that I love. When reading these, you will come across concepts you will want to pursue further. From math, engineering, solar systems and the universe, physics, language, gender, bioscience, oceanography, culture, anything you can think of and more. What do doulas do in various cultures and when did Western cultures stop using them and midwives and why? How are they used in Eastern cultures, if at all, and what about all the other cultures of the world?? This is only one question you may ask, and seeking that answer outside of the book, may well take the rest of your life to learn, to understand, and perhaps you will be the person to propel these concepts into mainstream again! Or change the entire childbirth field!! Most very intelligent scientists, lawyers, coders, etc., all started with scifi as children and went from there to where they are now, to wherever they push their fields in the future. Textbooks are meant to be one small part of learning about whatever it is about. From medical fields, chemistry, glassmaking, history, economics, home-ec, math, physics, military, ad naseum. Lecture and independent study and research are the other cornerstones of learning. I love going to all types of library sales in hundreds of miles any direction. I pick up a huge variety of encyclopedias, textbooks and medicinal plant books. One would think they are all alike, or have very minor differences. A chemistry book from the 1850s, 1900s, 1950s, 1970s, 1990s, 2010, 2015 will all have some major differences. From topics to how to do home chemistry to how to study chemistry will all have different information. I pick up as many medicinal plant books as I can as not all of the things a plant does is listed in one or ten, nor are there comprehensive pictures from seed to winter and how those plants subtly change appearance in various zones. For example, raspberry tea is generally considered to help a pregnant woman. However, what most modern texts and websites neglect to mention is that raspberry tea is also an abortificant and most pregnant women, or women attempting to become pregnant, should not drink it. Do many pregnant women drink it with no problems? Yes. There will always be an exception. Should women attempting to become pregnant who may have any difficulty doing so, or those who may struggle to retain a fetus, drink it? An emphatic no. Is that information widely disseminated? Not anymore. But you will find studies, both scientific and in the midwife communities and online, that regard raspberry tea as a huge problem and why. I am not in the medical field, nor am I a doula or midwife. I love reading. Taught myself to read at age 2 and have since outread libraries of various small towns to universities. I am not a fan of biographies, but other then that, any port in a storm. I gladly offer to talk about books, genres, how to read for your learning style, and about specific books. I love helping others learn to love reading and learning. Dont hesitate to contact me if you are interested in reading, but find it a mindless chore to do. I will strive to make it not just fun, but seek the educational aspects of any given book or genre, even biographies, and push you to continue learning!

No. Reading (obtaining more knowledge) can only increase the amount of your potential IQ that you actually use.Knowledge is not intelligence. If knowledge were intelligence, then we’d already have intelligent computers — computers can store tons of knowledge. Real IQ tests don’t test knowledge. According to the available scientific research, the vast majority of intelligence is hereditary. Although there is much scientific data to back this up, it remains a very unpopular idea. People desperately want IQ to be essentially environmental — if we can just provide the right stimulus for these disadvantaged children, they will develop higher IQs. The ugly truth is, every such attempt has failed — utterly.Read the book: The Bell Curve by Richard J. Herrnstein and Charles MurrayEnvironment seems only to dictate the amount of your potential IQ that you realize. Babies born to low IQ parents who were adopted out at birth or shortly thereafter to higher IQ parents, tended to have slightly higher IQs than their siblings who were not adopted out, but lower IQs than their adoptive siblings. The IQ of the adopted children more closely correlates with their biological siblings than with there adoptive siblings. You are born with a set potential of core intelligence — which cannot be changed. Your environment (upbringing, available resources [books, education level of your parents, IQ of your parents, opportunities to explore and learn], etc.) determines how much of your potential core intelligence you actually realize. Your IQ is a measure of your realized core intelligence.Although you cannot change your potential core intelligence, you can change how much of it you actually realize.Let’s say you have a potential of lifting 120 lbs. Currently, you can only lift 110 lbs. With practice, you can increase the amount you can actually lift, but you cannot increase that beyond your potential. Thus, in this case, you’d never be able to lift more than 120 lbs. — no matter how much you work at it. IQ is a measure of your realized core intelligence. If your potential IQ is 120, but your measured IQ is only 110, then you can increase your measured IQ to as high as 120, but no higher.Just as there’s no way to determine how much you can potentially lift — without pushing you to your limit and discovering what that limit is, there is no way of determining your potential IQ — without pushing you to your limit and discovering what that limit is. So, what can you do to get closer to your limit in IQ? Do things that require your brain to add new wiring — things that require you to learn new skills — mentally and physically. None of this is easy.Became fluent in a new language. The greater the difference between your native language and the new language, the greater the gain you’ll see. However, don’t expect much — maybe 10 points at the most. Once you’ve mastered one new language, start on another. Assuming English is your native language, consider languages in these groups: Slavic, African (except Afrikaans), Native American, Middle East, Far East. Avoid anything in the latin and germanic families.Learn to play a musical instrument — really well. Get a bachelor’s degree (or, preferably, higher) in music. I would suggest the piano or any of the non-fretted stringed instruments. Learn to ride a unicycle — studies have shown a high correlation between improved balance and better penmanship. Whatever learning to ride a unicycle does, it is adding new wiring in your brain and it carries over to other areas. Learn unicycle dance.Study mathematics. Get a bachelor’s degree (or, preferably, higher) in mathematics. Push yourself as far as you can go in mathematics.Study theoretical physics.Studying sample problems from IQ tests will boost your IQ score temporarily but will not provide lasting results and will not increase your actual IQ — only your IQ score. Read about the failure and redirection of the Head Start program to better understand the difference between increased IQ and increased IQ score. Head Start only produced a temporary increase in IQ score without actually increasing the IQ (which was the original stated goal of the program) of the participant children.

Books contain words. Words contain knowledge. Knowledge about people, places, and things across every time period. Knowledge about creative things that could inspire you to create yourself. Knowledge is power. It's so typical in our social media-obsessed, impatient generation to just skim over a post online, to the point where we can't even bring ourselves to read a full book, cover to cover. Even skim reading is being taught in schools. It is a skill to be learned, yes, but is a complete disservice when it comes to reading actual books. We don't even need to read books in school anymore thanks to the advent of things like Sparknotes. Therefore, if you can manage to sit through an entire book and actually comprehend it, assuming you are also an avid internet user, you have mastered the art of self-discipline and patience. Becoming smarter requires those two simple things. You don't need a ridiculously high IQ to become smarter. Self-discipline and patience allow you to be able to learn things quickly. And reading books is a step in the right direction for that.

It depends on your definition of smart. If you want to know a lot about a certain topic, then you should obviously read widely about that topic. For general smarts though, I would recommend reading everything you can get your hands on. Read fiction, non-fiction, poetry, scientific articles, the newspaper, everything. Reading helps to expand your vocabulary, because you will read words you have never heard anyone say before. Reading helps you to empathise with characters who may be extremely dissimilar to you, thus broadening your acceptance of other people and expanding your understanding of the world around you. The more you read, the more you will be able to identify good writing vs poor writing, which will in turn make you a better writer. You will be able to read other people’s thought processes, which will expand your own. By reading how other people solve problems, how they interpret the world around them (whether these people are real or fictional) you will be exposed to new methods to tackle your own problems, both academically and within general life. So while of course, experts on a certain topic are considered “smart” because of their expansive knowledge of a subject, everyone who reads, is smarter than someone who doesn’t.

It makes you better at reading. Reading is a quicker way to learn than have someone orally explain things to you. If you read, you can probably acquire new information faster than someone who relies on orally transmitted information like TV, radio, YouTube, the guy down the pub etc. So this can help make you better informed but not necessarily smarter. Yes, but the book you’re reading must have some sort of knowledge that you do not yet have. If you read a book that tells you about things that you already know, what you learn from that book will be limited. There is the book; and here is your mind. As you go through the pages, either you understand perfectly everything the author has to say or you do not. If you do, you may have gained information, but you could not have increased your understanding. If the book is completely intelligible to you from start to finish, then the author and you are as two minds of the same mold. The symbols on the page merely express the common understanding that you had before you met. — How to Read a Book: The Classic Guide to Intelligent Reading Gaining information would be learning facts to help prove that you are correct, for example, finding out about a study that proves free weights are better than machines. Gaining understanding is reading a book and not knowing about everything inside of it, for example, finding out about Pareto’s Principle when you know nothing about it. Thus we can roughly define what we mean by the art of reading as follows: the process whereby a mind, with nothing to operate on but the symbols of the readable matter, and with no help from outside, elevates itself by the power of its own operations. The mind passes from understanding less to understanding more. The skilled operations that cause this to happen are the various acts that constitute the art of reading. — How to Read a Book: The Classic Guide to Intelligent Reading Using the above definition, if you constantly read books that contain information that you do not yet understand, you’ll constantly gain the opportunity to increase your understanding and information about a topic. So in short, yes, but only if you read books containing information that you do not yet understand.

(Note: question changed by Quora for some inexplicable reason. See original question that addressed the issue of wisdom, nor becoming ‘smarter.’ My answer addresses WISDOM.) Wisdom comes from many sources. Books deliver wisdom if they are books that inform effectively: accurate, well written, useful, powerful, worthy. Newspapers, magazines, radio, television, the Internet . . . all sources of information and wisdom, much like books. They are all potential ‘wisdom media.’ (Note: assumes discriminating between quality media, or dreck.) Observing the world and judging good from evil, kind or cruel, appropriate vs. absurd, helpful compared with a waste of time . . . this ‘observing’ engages all six senses and adds wisdom. Critical judgment, a form of wisdom, emerges. Experiencing broadly, across many activities, and learning from them, will improve a person’s wisdom. Open the mind and heart. Live fully. That brings wisdom. It’s an observing and filtering process, and it offers many levels of acquisition. Think of it like this, in all the forms in which we sense the world: you can have immense amounts of data and little information, oodles of information and not much knowledge, and masses of knowledge but not much wisdom. The reduction from data to wisdom is many orders of magnitude. Wisdom enables a person to make wise decisions about things known to be true and right. Books—the true and right books—will deliver wisdom. The idea that one would even have to ask this question is . . . amazing. It shows a lack of wisdom.

I can’t say if it makes people smarter, but I know that for me reading seems to have expanded my concept of things. Even reading predominantly fiction can increase vocabulary, which in turn can allow your mind to follow and form more complex concepts. In 1984, George Orwell had his fictional government outlawing words to limit the ability of the populace for independent thought. If you don’t know a word to express concepts like “freedom” and “autonomy”, even if you have it in your mind, you cannot easily communicate such ideas to others. In Ayn Rand’s “Anthem”, similar language restrictions were used too, for similar reasons. The word “I” was banned, to emphasis the collective. Reading allows you to both learn from the topic being read, as well as improving brain connectivity. I also think that fiction especially is an exercise in empathy. If you have the ability to feel what the character feels, to exist in their life for a while, you are exercising empathy. (Perhaps the drop off in voluntary reading correlates with the lack of empathy observed in the modern world).

Maybe because our consciousness likes being fed by information and data. It widens our perspective and enables us to see more options in solving a problem. Let's say you're blindfolded. I then lead you to a desk. Then I give you a problem. I put a cake in front of you on the desk. Then I task you to cut the cake in half. “With what?” You say. That's an illustration of people who barely read. Then I inform you that there are tools on desk that you can use to cut the cake. “Ah.” You say. The abstract idea acquired by someone who reads moderately. Than I add, there are only three tools on the desk, placed close to the cake: A pencil, a knife, and a plastic straw. “Oh, of course!” You exclaim and carefully search for the knife around the cake. Because you also know that knives are usually sharp and you're blindfolded. That's, I think, how more information from reading help you solve problems. To be more realistic, the process usually guides us to gradually learn the nature of the knife and the accepted customary of using it to cut a cake, and many other details. Different reading genres require different approach. Some stimulate your logic, some fertilize your sentiments, others encourage your rationality, but all of them require imagination. In the future, when you’re faced with various problems, you'd realize multiple pragmatic options and formulate a decision.

Reading increases your concentration skills, and leads you to be more aware of where and how to find information that you want or need — in which kinds of books, shelved where in your library of local bookstore. It can also sharpen your pattern-spotting ability (following plots of stories, development of characters real or fictional, organizing information from a non-fiction book in your mind). Reading has had the greatest effect on my understanding of myself and empathy for others. Because I have vicariously experienced many life events and traumas first in books, they were not as frightening when they popped up in real life. Because I have learned to love characters from many economic levels and from different cultures, I am more open in real life meetings with people who are different from me. Reading has also increased my knowledge in some areas: vocabulary, grammar, writing, geography, and history. It has piqued my interest and triggered further study in the sciences, religion, the Bible, and foreign languages. But there are other intelligences I have not developed through reading. I would not say I have learned as much about time management or money management either. I haven't learned to be a good gardener, to make useful things, to fix my car or to be a good cook from reading, but other people may have. I learn some things better from other people teaching me directly, and some things I may always struggle with. But that helps me appreciate those who have instinctive or learned intelligence in those areas. Everyone has something to contribute.

Whether it actually makes you smarter is probably a question best left up to neurologists and psychologists. However, reading makes you a better educated, more rounded person by exposing you to information and ideas in a way that you would not normally encounter. I guess what I’m trying to say is that I don’t know if it actually makes you smarter (it may) but I think it definitely helps you make better use of whatever intelligence you have by broadening your horizons.

response.answer_text: No, it doesn't. It makes you more informed. It gives you access to new vistas of ideas and information.  Whether or not you use and understand those ideas and information is what makes you smarter. And you can't use or understand them if you didn't have access to the ideas and information in the first place. And any literary work can work if there is some range of the ideas conveyed in the work. It may be non-fiction related to some particular field. It may also be fiction where you study the human (or anthropomorphic) psyche and behavior in a world of the author's creation.

Finally, in College , my professor gently insisted that everyone invest in a book called “the book of cultural literacy—-what every American should know”.

Too complicated and broad a question. Smart people tend to like information. Not just reading. Experiences, discussions about ideas, any way to find out something new and interesting. And then, generally, they like pondering that new information. So not just consuming to consume, but also figuring out how the “meal” was put together in terms of ingredients. I would say reading fluff (romance novels, some graphic novels) does not make you smarter. If you want to read for “smartness” read something challenging, that you are also interested in. So if you like cooking, read a science book on the chemistry of cooking. Or watch videos on food science. Or, in my case, I like science. So I read books written for lay people on topics like absolute zero or fractal geometry. I’ll never be a scientist, but it helps me think about the things I already know in a different way.

A man in search of knowledge has an unlimited source to gather it in the modern times and make himself smarter. Yet it had a humble beginning in the books and we shall ever be indebted for that. Long live the books.

This is especially true for reading fiction. Non-fiction can in theory make you clever because you are learning something new. Reading will not turn you into Einstein, but it will enhance you and the quality of your life.

Not in itself, no. Reading certainly can help you to develop your intellectual capabilities - and is usually a very important part of becoming more intelligent. What's much more important, however, in terms of boosting your intelligence, is how you react to what you've read. If reading leads to you questioning things, then it is indeed likely to help you improve your intelligence. If, however, you merely passively absorb what you've read, unquestioningly, this might boost your knowledge, but it can have a limited or even distinctly negative impact on your intelligence. Being intelligent is largely about having a questioning mind. If reading is to make you more intelligent, then it needs to provoke questions, not just provide answers. Gifted

The answer to your question is: books may make you smarter by increasing your experiences so you know more about how your world functions and how you can get the most from it and avoid making costly mistakes. All real experience (good or bad) makes a person smarter. Book learning is a substitute for real experience, and may make you smarter, or dumber depending on the intent of the authors. If you don’t know anything when you read a book, you won’t get anything from it. The more you know when you read books, the more you get out of them and the more you are able to reject false facts and constructs. When smart people read books, they argue with the material, that exercises the brain and sharpens it’s capabilities.
